title: 107_hr3515
content: The "International Student Responsibility Act" is the short title of the Act. It focuses on foreign state assistance in ensuring that prospective students are eligible for admission into the United States. Upon receiving a visa application from a foreign national for certain nonimmigrant statuses, the Secretary of State must request information from the foreign state regarding any grounds of inadmissibility or potential violations of status. Enforcement measures apply to citizens and nationals of the foreign state in question. The Secretary of State may deem citizens and nationals of a state ineligible for certain nonimmigrant visas if the state fails to respond to requests or if a substantial number of individuals violate their visa conditions. This enforcement measure applies to citizens and nationals of the foreign state in question. Restriction on admissibility of nonimmigrant students from state sponsors of international terrorism. No visa for nonimmigrant students from state sponsors of international terrorism unless determined not a threat to US security by Secretary of State and Attorney General. Consultation with other US agencies required for such determinations. The term "state sponsor of international terrorism" is defined as a country whose government has repeatedly supported acts of international terrorism, as determined by the Secretary of State under specific laws. These laws include the Export Administration Act of 1979, the Arms Export Control Act, and the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. SEC. 4. Notice to educational institutions of entry into United States by prospective student. The Attorney General will notify approved institutions of higher education, other educational institutions, and exchange visitor programs when an alien is admitted to the US for studying or participating in a program, within 10 days of entry. SEC. 5. Additional obligations of educational institutions under foreign student monitoring program. The amendment to the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 requires aliens to register with the institution or program in the US before the scheduled start date of their instruction or participation. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of State and the Secretary of Education, will establish a process to collect information from approved educational institutions and exchange visitor programs in the US regarding nationals of all countries. This process will be in effect until the Attorney General completes the data collection. The Attorney General will collect information electronically under the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. Information received will be included in the National Crime Information Center's Interstate Identification Index. Civil money penalties will be imposed for failure to provide information. The Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 (8 U.S.C. 1372(d)(2)) is amended to revoke approvals or visas and impose civil penalties of at least $25,000 for failure to provide specified information by approved educational institutions or exchange visitor programs. The Attorney General will enforce these penalties according to the procedures outlined in the Act. The Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 is amended to impose civil penalties under specific provisions for non-compliance by educational institutions or exchange visitor programs. Final transcripts and diplomas may be withheld until immigration obligations are fulfilled. The Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 amended to impose civil penalties for non-compliance by educational institutions or exchange visitor programs. Final transcripts and diplomas cannot be released for nonimmigrant aliens until they depart the US or change immigration status. The Attorney General will ensure that educational institutions receive necessary information on alien departures and changes in immigration status to comply with regulations. If an institution violates these regulations, the Attorney General will enforce penalties. The Attorney General has the authority to revoke approval for issuing documents or impose civil penalties on educational institutions for violating visa eligibility requirements for aliens under certain categories. The Attorney General can revoke approval or penalize educational institutions for violating visa eligibility requirements for aliens under specific categories, including the establishment of mandatory forms and direct consulate submission for aliens outside the US. Additionally, the Higher Education Act now includes a certification requirement for institutions regarding their approval status under certain sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Attorney General has the authority to revoke or deny documents for visa eligibility under certain categories for aliens, as stated in the Immigration and Nationality Act. Authorization of appropriations for SEVIS includes funding for the operation of the Student and Exchange Visitors Information System and investigation/enforcement activities based on its data for fiscal years 2002-2006.
